channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Cholera Deepens Haiti’s Misery After Hurricane
item.media:description: A small makeshift clinic in Rendel, Haiti, is overflowing with cholera patients.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The disease is stalking the areas gutted by Hurricane Matthew on a remote stretch of the country’s southern peninsula.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Obama, Cementing New Ties With Cuba, Lifts Limits on Cigars and Rum
item.media:description: Tourists buying cigars from a shop in Havana. President Obama on Friday lifted the $100 limit on bringing Cuban rum and cigars into the United States.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: In a sweeping directive, President Obama pressed forward in the face of lingering opposition in Congress to repealing the Cold War trade embargo.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Nicolás Maduro Flexes New Budgetary Muscles in Venezuela
item.description: A legal expert called the budget “openly unconstitutional” after a Supreme Court decision stripped the National Assembly of its power of the purse.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and ANA VANESSA HERRERO

item.title: Thailand Looks to Likely Future King With Apprehension
item.media:description: Crown Prince Vajiralongkorn with his mother, on his left, and sisters in Bangkok in 2010.
item.description: Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn’s lavish European lifestyle and tastes for airplanes, fast cars, women and the high life have caused anxiety.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bhumibol, a King of the People, Leaves Them to the Generals
item.media:description: King Bhumibol Adulyadej stands with his mother (left), princess Srinagarindra (the Princess mother), and queen Sirikit (right) in 1982.
item.description: Democracy never was King Bhumibol’s goal for Thailand. Restoring the traditional influence of the monarchy was.
item.dc:creator: PAUL HANDLEY

item.title: Saudi-Led Coalition Says It Bombed Yemen Funeral Based on False Information
item.description: The attack killed at least 100 people, and the admission was a rare acknowledgment by the coalition that it had hit a civilian site.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Jordan Tones Down Textbooks’ Islamic Content, and Tempers Rise
item.media:description: Protesters in Maan, a desert town in southern Jordan, rallied late last month against changes to classroom materials that trimmed references to Islam.
item.description: An effort to help youths avoid drifting to extreme ideologies has provoked a backlash, with many viewing the curriculum tweaks as a declaration of war on Islamic values.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Critic's Notebook: Berlin, 1945; Grozny, 2000; Aleppo, 2016
item.media:description: Six siblings outside their tent in Zaatari, a Syrian refugee camp in Jordan.
item.description: In Aleppo, a drone video reveals a destruction so complete that it obliterates even a sense of time.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

item.title: Politics Trumps Gender in the Selection of a U.N. Leader
item.media:description: Matthew Rycroft, the British ambassador to the United Nations. Of the five permanent Security Council members, only Britain openly championed the idea of a female secretary general.
item.description: The candidacies of the seven women vying to become the next secretary general collapsed from what critics called a clubby culture dominated by men.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Behind Putin’s Combativeness, Some See Motives Other Than Syria
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow on Wednesday. Incomes are falling in Russia for the first time since 2000.
item.description: Some analysts believe the Russian leader’s strong response to criticism from Western leaders may be a way to deflect attention from simmering domestic problems.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Nations, Fighting Powerful Refrigerant That Warms Planet, Reach Landmark Deal
item.description: A binding accord on a heat-trapping chemical used in air-conditioners and refrigerators could have a greater impact on global warming than the Paris pact of 2015.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Thailand Says Bhumibol’s Cremation Is a Year Away, With Heir’s Coronation to Follow
item.description: The crown prince has asked that King Bhumibol’s cremation be held after a one-year period of mourning, with his own coronation to come later, an official said.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: With Idols in Ranks, South Korean Army Steps to a K-Pop Beat
item.media:description: One of South Korea’s most famous K-pop stars, U-Know Yunho, center, performing this month at a military festival in Gyeryong, South Korea.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Military service is compulsory for young men, even celebrities, who perform in military bands and at an annual promotional festival.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Stampede Kills at Least 24 at Hindu Ceremony in India
item.description: Organizers in Uttar Pradesh, a northern province, expected 3,000 people, but a bridge became overcrowded when more than 70,000 showed up.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Rise of Saudi Prince Shatters Decades of Royal Tradition
item.media:description: President Obama with King Salman of Saudi Arabia, to his right, at a Group of 20 summit meeting in Turkey in November.
item.description: Prince Mohammed bin Salman has quickly emerged as the most dynamic royal in the Arab world’s wealthiest nation, setting up a potential rivalry for the throne.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Attacks by ISIS Kill Dozens in Iraq
item.media:description: A suicide bomber detonated explosives at a Shiite gathering in the Shaab district of Baghdad, killing at least 41 people.
item.description: Three attacks took place as Iraqi forces were preparing an offensive to take back Mosul, the last city still under the Islamic State’s control.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: India Police Pressed to Act in Girl’s Death After Fast
item.description: The girl was a devoted follower of Jainism, a religion that celebrates radical acts of renunciation. Her parents may faces charges of culpable homicide in her death.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: 24 Killed in Stampede Ahead of Hindu Ceremony in India
item.description: At least 24 people were killed and 20 others injured in a stampede that occurred as they were crossing a crowded bridge to reach a Hindu religious ceremony in northern India on Saturday, police said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: American Aid Worker Kidnapped in Niger, Official Says
item.description: Gunmen stormed the house of a longtime American aid worker in Niger, killing two people before fleeing with the man toward the border with Mali, authorities said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: El Salvador Wins Dispute Over Denying a Mining Permit
item.description: An international arbitration panel ruled that the government did not have to pay compensation to Pac Rim Cayman for denying it a concession to drill for gold.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.category: International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes

item.title: Jim Prentice, Former Premier of Alberta, Dies in Plane Crash
item.description: Mr. Prentice, who also served in the cabinet of former Prime Minister Stephen Harper, was a widely respected moderate Conservative in Canada politics.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Diver Recounts His Encounter With a Cage-Breaking Great White Shark
item.description: “Honestly at that moment I don’t have time to get afraid,” Chan Ming, the diver, said of the encounter with a shark that broke through the bars of a diving cage.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Canada Today: Economic Bright Spots, and Some Disquieting Mail
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, right, with Jim Smith, the chief executive of Thomson Reuters, last week. Thomson Reuters has announced that its senior executives will move to Toronto, a decision that may create up to 1,500 new jobs.
item.description: Thomson Reuters, the global digital information company, said it would move its senior executives to Toronto, and two automakers made deals with Canadian plants.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: In Nigeria, Joy for Girls Freed by Boko Haram. What of the Rest?
item.media:description: President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Berlin on Friday. He had made securing the release of the abducted girls a cornerstone of his campaign last year for the presidency.
item.description: The country celebrated the release of 21 girls whom Boko Haram had seized from their school in April 2014, but many others remain unaccounted for.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A ‘Balloon Warrior’ Subverts North Korea, Thousands of Leaflets at a Time
item.media:description: Lee Min-bok, a North Korean defector, getting ready to release balloons with bags of leaflets to North Korea near the Demilitarized Zone.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Reviving a Cold War tactic, a North Korean defector airdrops materials that he says will puncture the personality cult surrounding Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Grieving Thais Line Streets of Bangkok to Pay Tribute to King
item.media:description: Soldiers secured the route of the royal procession in Bangkok, the Thai capital.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Signs of loss were inescapable in Bangkok as tens of thousands of people gathered to watch the procession of King Bhumibol Adulyadej’s coffin.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Joseph L. Birman, Physicist Who Aided Dissident Scientists, Dies at 89
item.media:description: Joseph L. Birman, a professor of theoretical physics, was widely known for his work to help refugee scientists.
item.description: Dr. Birman was instrumental in the creation of a program that helped refugee scientists restart their careers in the United States in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: ANITA GATES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: What in the World: On London’s Fleet Street, the Presses Have Stopped for Good
item.media:description: The Daily Telegraph’s offices around 1969, when Fleet Street in London was full of newspaper offices.
item.description: Two employees of a Scottish paper who left recently were the last newspaper journalists actually working on the street that gave the British press its nickname.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: What in the World: Who’s That Voice Asking for Scrap Metal in Mexico? A 10-Year-Old Girl
item.description: A collector of recyclable goods got tired of shouting through a megaphone, so he asked his daughter to record a message for him. It’s now used by hundreds of merchants.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Abroad in America: ‘The Wall Is a Fantasy’
item.media:description: Nogales, Ariz. The American side of the border fence.
item.media:credit: Tomás Munita for The New York Times
item.description: A week in the borderlands with migrants and guards.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Opinion: Why Chinese Women Still Can’t Get a Break
item.description: Social changes that have given urban Chinese women new liberties and ambitions often impede their freedom in other ways.
item.dc:creator: HELEN GAO

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Can a Mayor Succeed Where Presidents Fail?
item.media:description: Mayor Anne Hidalgo of Paris in Beirut, Lebanon, last month.
item.description: The globally conscious mayor of Paris gets things done. But inviting traffic jams and proposing a nudist camp may not be the best places to start.
item.dc:creator: SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
